column4: Sorry, I meant What causes a partition to or not to be listed with the command ls /dev/disk/by-uuid -alh?
scunizi:  blkid does not list the partition in question.
scunizi:  I cannot get to it.  I tried to change the permissions on it, not realizing that I needed to do that in fstab.
scunizi:  No.  It is one of two drives.  The drive has two partitions, the smaller of which is my linux filesystem, which I'm using right now.
scunizi: Failed to access '/dev/disk/by-uuid/621C7C841C7C554F': No such file or directory
scunizi:  Where does a uuid come from?
scunizi:  What does mount -a do?  I tried commenting it out but mount -a doesn't do anything.
I made the mistake of logging in as root and trying to change the permissions on an NTFS permission instead of using fstab.  Now that partition will not mount.  What can I do?
you need to install 'ntfsprogs' and run 'ntfsfix /dev/sdaX' to fix the permissions corruption
Mounting volume... Failed to startup volume : Invalid argument
this isn't really an NTFS problem then.  You have a corrupted filesystem.
How can this be?  I was using this drive all day today?  It wasn't until I tried to change the permissions that this started.
Are you telling me that simply trying to change the permissions on a partition can corrupt the entire partition?!
it really depends on what happened, how clean the filesystem was to begin with and how old the disk is, but yes
